docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re your July 31 front-page article on the Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield debacle in Ohio: While Anthem and many other health maintenance organizations derive their income from lump-sum payments based on capitation for each patient enrolled, they still pay providers in the traditional way, essentially fee for service.

headline.main: Medicine Isn't Attracting Best and Brightest; H.M.O. Fees

docs.abstract: Letter from Dr Myron E Wegman, dean emeritus of University of Michigan's School of Public Health, disputes July 31 article on Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield debacle in Ohio; says it is mistake to tar all HMO's with same brush since many are providing substantially lower costs while maintaining customer satisfaction (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Arthur T. Barbieri, who helped build the city's Democratic Party into a political machine that continues to wield power, helped start the political careers of many prominent politicians and even worked with a young volunteer named Bill Clinton, died on Sunday at the Connecticut Hospice in Branford. He was 82 and lived in New Haven. The cause was cancer, The New Haven Register reported on Monday.

headline.main: Arthur T. Barbieri, 82, Democrat Who Built New Haven Machine

docs.abstract: Arthur T Barbieri, who helped build New Haven, Conn, Democratic Party into political machine that continues to wield power, dies at age 82 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Julie Zuckerman and Josh Kulp, an American couple who moved to Israel three years ago, did not know what to expect when they shopped for their first mortgage here. What they got was a dizzying education in one of the more complicated home finance systems in the developed world. Ms. Zuckerman, a vice president of an investment bank, and Mr. Kulp, a teacher of Judaic studies, now own a $212,000 five-bedroom duplex in Modi'in, one of the new towns that has sprung up along the 40-mile highway between Jerusalem and Tel Aviv. But it took three loans, at three interest rates, to make that possible.

headline.main: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Land of Homeowners; Most Israelis Own Houses, but Oh Those Mortgages

docs.abstract: About 73 percent of Israel's five million citizens live in privately owned homes, compared with 66 percent in US; mortgage system has been tool to foster land development and further other social ends; creaky mortgage system is at crossroads, scrambling to find ways to keep making new loans; system, holdover from early days of statehood, when Israel's socialist nature promised home for every citizen, has had to expand to accommodate ever more populous and diverse country; it has also had to adjust as nation has lurched from heavy state control to free market economy; despite Government's traditionally deep role in mortgage market, officials are balking at providing loan guarantees, which would make bundled mortgages more attractive to investors; chart; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It has been clear that there are major differences to be worked out between the Democratic and Republican bills on patient rights. But a look at the details of the House Republican plan shows that there are also major differences in important areas on which the two sides had seemed to agree.

headline.main: Common Ground on Patient Rights Hides a Chasm

docs.abstract: Detailed look at Republican bill on patients' rights shows major differences in important areas in which it seemed to agree with Democratic plan and that both sides are farther apart than originally thought; differences in emergency medical services and privacy of patients' medical records discussed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Scene I: Late afternoon, offices of a large Manhattan law firm. Stanley Bojarski, a tall, animated man, hunches over a computer terminal. He wears a gray pinstripe suit, retro-ish geometric tie, black tasseled loafers. At his right elbow is a stack of papers, legal briefs or depositions, which he periodically leafs through. Scene II: Some hours later, a 199-seat West Side theater. A mermaid in a blue wig and bosomy nude fishtailed body-mold cavorts onstage, to crowd guffaws. It is . . . Stanley Bojarski!

headline.main: Pinstripes by Day, Chiffon by Night; Straitlaced Jobs May Pay the Rent, But Outrageousness Feeds the Soul

docs.abstract: Countless actors off and on Broadway are waiting tables, modeling, driving taxicabs, painting apartments and spraying cologne on shoppers in Bloomingdale's to pay the rent and be able to pursue their real dream at night; few, however, have their feet planted in two such contrasting worlds as Stanley Bojarski, legal assistant in large law firm by day, and actor and comic female impersonator in show When Pigs Fly at night; another member of cast, James Heatherly, works for bank; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''What About a Bill of Rights for the Uninsured?'' (Op-Ed, July 28): Even during the period when managed care was not heavily regulated and seemed to be bringing health care costs under control, the ranks of the uninsured continued to grow. Subsequently, with the failure of the Clinton plan, the number of people without coverage has risen steadily, to an estimated 41.7 million.
docs.abstract: Letter by Catherine M Dunham, national program director of Access Project at Brandeis University, comments on growing ranks of the medically uninsured (July 28 Op-Ed article)

docs.lead_paragraph: Most people watching the Lewis County Fair parade had no idea who the man in the monogrammed shirt was or why he had joined the procession of baton twirlers, beauty queens and Boy Scouts marching through town on a steamy summer night. He was politely shaking hands, and occasionally introducing himself as Jim Larocca, a Democratic candidate for governor. But he was not urging people to support him in the Democratic primary on Sept. 15. And unlike other politicians marching in the parade, he had no zealous campaign aides passing out buttons and shouting his name to the crowd.

headline.main: A Candidate Without Cash or Flash; Larocca's Understated Race, the Weakest in a Field of Four

docs.abstract: Article in series The 1998 Campaign: The Race for Governor, examines candidacy of James L Larocca for Democratic nomination for New York State Governor; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Russell Baker (column, July 31) has it just right about the health care mess we are in. Our elected representatives ought to be downright ashamed of themselves.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton on Tuesday will announce new policies making it easier for states to provide Medicaid to adults in two-parent families who work at low-wage jobs for more than 100 hours a month. Administration officials said the changes would help 135,000 to 200,000 people in 20 states. Thirty states had already received permission from the Federal Government to dispense with the 100-hour-a-month rule.

headline.main: Clinton to Expand Medicaid For Some of the Working Poor

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton will announce new policies making it easier for states to provide Medicaid to adults in two-parent families who work at low-wage jobs for more than 100 hours per month; Administration officials say changes will help 135,000 to 200,000 people in 20 states; 37 states have already received permission to dispense with 100-hour-a-month rule (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It has been 22 years since a young pediatrician named Earl R. Washburn 3d hung his shingle in this rustic old gold-mining town in the foothills of the Sierras. There were no pediatricians in Placerville back then; with fewer than 7,000 people, there was not even a McDonald's. But the town, with its towering pines and firs, charming turn-of-the-century cottages and proximity to the state capital, Sacramento, seemed a fine place to set up practice and raise a family. And Dr. Washburn, fresh out of residency with a wife and 15-month-old son, had very definite ideas on how to do both.

headline.main: As Doctors Trade Shingle For Marquee, Cries of Woe

docs.abstract: First article in After the Revolution, series examining effects of managed care on nation's health care system, focuses on doctors' loss of independence over past five years' of medical mergers and acquisitions; many doctors have sold practices outright, trading patient charts for cash payments and employee status at hospitals, HMO's or 'physician practice management' firms; American Medical Assn says that approximately 43 percent of nation's physicians worked for someone else in 1997, up from 24 percent in 1983, and that 92 percent of doctors had some type of managed-care contract during that year; doctors have had to learn to cope with burdensome paperwork, discounted fees and insurance company restrictions on specialists they refer to and drugs they prescribe, but what troubles them most are intangibles that have been lost, such as building their own practices on their own terms and forging bonds with patients that last through years, no matter which insurance company pays bills; article examines effects of changes on Sacramento, Calif, where 90 percent of all insured people are enrolled in health maintenance organizations, where doctors have lost jobs and patients amid intense competition for work, and where collegiality is all but gone; charts; photos (L)
